Checkboxes

Checkboxes are used when the user can make one or more selections from a list or group of options.

Form Checkboxes

This style of checkboxes is commonly used in forms. Users can select one or more options. If only one option can be selected, use radio buttons. Checkbox icons and their labels should be left-aligned and vertical for better scannability when appropriate.

Unselected

24 px
24 px

BACKGROUND
color: #FFFFFF;
border: 2px #707070;
border-radius: 2px;

BACKGROUND
color: #006546;

color: #FFFFFF;

border: 2px #BBBBBB;

Click Target

A checkbox can be selected and deselected by clicking or tapping on the checkbox as well as the text label.

Card Checkboxes

Card checkboxes are used in interactive tools. The element allows space for icons when appropriate, as well as typographical hierarchy. The entire card is a large touch/click target which minimizes user input error and allows for an easier interaction on a mobile device. Users can select one or more options. If only one option can be selected, use card radio buttons.

Specs

Card height and width are flexible based on specific use cases. The cards are most commonly used in a ⅓ or ¼ grid layout. Icons can be used with different typography hierarchy inside the card. All elements should stay within the specified padding requirements below.

Unselected

CARD
background: #FFFFFF;
border: 2px #BBBBBB;
box-shadow: 0 1px 4px 0 #BBBBBB;
border-radius: 2px;

Click Target

The entire card in card checkboxes should be clickable.

Accessibility

Checkboxes should show a visible focus state when tabbed to by a user. Using the “Space” key toggles the focused checkbox between selected and unselected states.

User interface components should meet 3:1 color contrast ratio requirements. This includes the border of the checkbox and the contrast between a selected checkbox background and the checkmark in the checkbox.

References

https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices-1.1/#checkbox
https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/non-text-contrast.html
